speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio wonders where Romeo is and if he came home last night. Tonight here means last night.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio says Romeo did not go to his father's house, because he spoke with Romeo's servant.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio blames Rosaline, calling her a pale, hard-hearted woman, for tormenting Romeo so much that he will surely go mad.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio reports that Tybalt, a relative of old Capulet, has sent a letter to Romeo's father's house.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio immediately assumes it is a challenge to a duel.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio believes Romeo will respond to the challenge.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio jokes that anyone who can write can answer a letter, playing on the word answer.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio clarifies that Romeo will answer Tybalt himself, accepting the dare.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio mocks Romeo as already defeated by love: wounded by Rosaline's glance, pierced by a love song, and struck by Cupid's blunt arrow. He doubts Romeo can fight Tybalt. Butt-shaft means a blunt arrow for practice.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks what kind of fighter Tybalt is.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio describes Tybalt as an expert, formal duelist who follows all the rules precisely, like a musician keeping time. He uses fencing terms like passado and punto reverso, calling him a prince of cats from folklore.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks for clarification about the fencing terms.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio complains about affected, fashionable people who use newfangled speech and manners, calling them flies and fashion-mongers who care more about style than comfort.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio announces Romeo's arrival.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio jokes that Romeo looks thin and lovelorn, comparing him to a dried fish. He mockingly says Romeo's new love inspires bad love poetry, dismissing famous beauties like Laura and Cleopatra as unremarkable. He greets Romeo in French, mocking his fashionable loose trousers and his absence the previous night.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo returns the greeting and asks what trick or deception Mercutio means.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He asks if Romeo cannot understand the slip, meaning an escape or evasion, teasing him for sneaking away.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He apologizes, saying his business was important and in such circumstances a man may be excused for being impolite.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He jokes that Romeo’s case forces a man to bow at the knees, implying Romeo was with a woman.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He clarifies that Mercutio means to curtsy, acknowledging the bawdy implication.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He says Romeo has exactly understood his meaning.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He calls Mercutio’s explanation very polite, with ironic praise.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He boasts that he is the very model or perfect example of courtesy.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He notes that pink means a flower, playing on the word.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He agrees with Romeo’s point.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He quips that his shoe is well decorated with flowers, punning on pump as a shoe and flowered as ornamented.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He urges Romeo to keep up the jest until his shoe is worn out, so the joke outlasts the shoe and remains uniquely clever.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He mocks the joke as thin and solitary, playing on single-soled (cheap) and solely singular (alone).

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He calls for Benvolio to intervene because his wit is exhausted.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He urges Mercutio to use switches and spurs to speed his wit, or he will claim victory in their contest.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He says if Romeo’s wits lead them on a wild-goose chase, he gives up, for Romeo has more foolishness in one wit than he has in all five senses, asking if he followed the goose joke.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He retorts that Mercutio was never with him in anything unless he was there for the foolishness, turning the insult back.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio jokingly threatens to bite Romeo's ear for his witty remark, a playful gesture of mock aggression.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo calls Mercutio a 'good goose' and tells him not to bite, continuing the banter with a food metaphor.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He says Romeo's wit is like a bitter apple or sharp sauce—pungent and biting.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo retorts that such sharp wit is appropriately paired with a sweet goose, turning the insult back on Mercutio.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He praises Romeo's flexible wit, comparing it to cheveril (kid leather) that stretches from narrow to broad.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo twists 'broad' to call Mercutio a 'broad goose'—a foolish woman—extending the pun to insult him.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He approves of Romeo's return to sociable banter instead of lovesick moping, comparing love to a foolish jester hiding his toy.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio interrupts, urging Mercutio to stop his crude story.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio quips that Benvolio wants him to stop 'against the hair'—against his natural grain or desire.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio replies that otherwise Mercutio would have made his story large (long or indecent).

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio claims he was already finished and meant to occupy the argument no longer, denying any intent to prolong it.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo exclaims 'Here’s goodly gear!' and 'A sail, a sail!'—mocking the Nurse's arrival as if spotting a ship.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He adds 'Two, two; a shirt and a smock,' joking that both a man (Peter) and woman (Nurse) have arrived.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse calls for her servant Peter.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter responds 'Anon,' meaning 'right away.'

speaker: NURSE
content: She asks Peter for her fan, showing her fussy demeanor.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He jests that the Nurse should hide her face because her fan is more attractive than her face. This insult mocks her appearance and sets a bawdy tone for their exchange.

speaker: NURSE
content: She greets the gentlemen with a formal 'God give you good morning.'

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He replies with 'God give you good evening,' deliberately using the wrong time of day to mock her.

speaker: NURSE
content: She questions whether it is indeed evening, showing her confusion at his jest.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He insists it is evening because the 'bawdy hand' (sexual pun on clock hand) is on the 'prick' (pun on noon marker and penis) of noon. This crude time-telling continues his sexual mockery.

speaker: NURSE
content: She exclaims 'Shame on you!' and questions what kind of man he is.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says he is a man God made to ruin, self-deprecatingly playing along with Mercutio's humor.

speaker: NURSE
content: She agrees with his remark, repeating 'for himself to mar' with approval, then asks where to find young Romeo. Her malapropism 'quoth a' for 'quoth he' shows her comic character.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says he can tell her, but Romeo will be older when found than when sought, playing with time. He identifies himself as the youngest of that name 'for fault of a worse' - meaning only because there's no worse one.

speaker: NURSE
content: She simply says 'You speak well,' either missing or ignoring his wordplay.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He puns on Romeo's 'for fault of a worse,' asking if 'the worst' is 'well,' then praises the wordplay as 'wisely taken.'

speaker: NURSE
content: She asks to speak privately with Romeo, but misuses 'confidence' for 'conference' (private conversation), another malapropism.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He jokes that she will 'endite' (malapropism for 'invite') him to supper, playing on her verbal errors.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He shouts 'A bawd, a bawd!' (procuress) and 'So ho!' (hunting cry), implying the Nurse is a prostitute hunting for Romeo.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks what Mercutio has found, playing along with the hunting metaphor.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He says he found no hare (slang for prostitute) unless it's an old, stale one in a Lenten pie. His song continues the metaphor: an old gray-haired hare is good Lenten food, but one that's moldy ('hoar') before being eaten is too much for twenty people. He then invites Romeo to his father's for dinner.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo agrees to follow his friends, showing his eagerness to leave the scene.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio mockingly bids farewell to the Nurse, repeating 'lady' to exaggerate her age and social pretensions.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse asks Romeo who that rude man was, using 'saucy merchant' for an impudent fellow and 'ropery' for roguish tricks.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo dismisses Mercutio as a man who talks a lot but does little, highlighting Mercutio's boastful nature.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse angrily vows to punish anyone who insults her, calling Mercutio a 'scurvy knave' (worthless rascal) and denying she is one of his 'flirt-gills' (loose women) or 'skains-mates' (cutthroat companions), then scolds Peter for not defending her.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter defensively says he saw no one mistreat her and claims he would have drawn his weapon if needed, provided the quarrel was just and legal.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse, still agitated, says she is trembling with anger, then shifts to her mission: she warns Romeo not to lead Juliet into a 'fool's paradise' (false hopes) or deceive her, stressing Juliet's youth and the seriousness of such betrayal.

speaker: NURSE
content: She excitedly interrupts Romeo, saying she will tell Juliet his protestation (declaration), which she interprets as a proper offer from a gentleman.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks what she plans to tell Juliet, noting she isn't listening properly.

speaker: NURSE
content: She repeats that she will tell Juliet about his protest, which she considers gentlemanly.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo instructs the Nurse to have Juliet find a way to go to confession ('shrift') at Friar Lawrence's cell this afternoon, where she will be confessed ('shriv'd') and married, and he offers payment for her trouble.

speaker: NURSE
content: She politely refuses the money.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He insists she take it.

speaker: NURSE
content: She agrees that Juliet will be there this afternoon.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo tells the Nurse to wait behind the abbey wall; within an hour his servant will bring a rope ladder ('cords made like a tackled stair') that will serve as his means ('convoy') to reach the height ('topgallant') of his joy at night. He bids her be trustworthy and he will reward her.

speaker: NURSE
content: She blesses him and asks him to listen.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks the Nurse what she has to say, showing his eagerness for news from Juliet.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse asks if Romeo's servant is trustworthy, using a proverb meaning that a secret is safe with two people if one is removed.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo assures her his servant is completely reliable, using 'true as steel' to mean steadfast.

speaker: NURSE
content: She praises Juliet's sweetness and mentions Paris's unwanted advances; Juliet prefers a toad to him. The Nurse teases Juliet by praising Paris, making her turn pale. She then playfully links Romeo and rosemary by their initial letter.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo confirms both words start with 'R', prompting the Nurse's jest about dog sounds.

speaker: NURSE
content: She jokes that 'R' sounds like a dog's growl, then recalls Juliet's clever sayings about Romeo and rosemary, which would please him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo politely asks the Nurse to give his greetings to Juliet.

speaker: NURSE
content: She agrees enthusiastically and calls for her servant Peter, as Romeo exits.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter responds 'Anon,' meaning 'right away' or 'I'm coming.'

speaker: NURSE
content: She urges Peter to go ahead of her and quickly, showing her haste to return to Juliet.
